segment.source: You can use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) command-line interface (CLI) to generate a new Windows 10 Mobile image.
segment.target: You can use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) command-line interface (CLI) to generate a new Windows 10 Mobile image.

segment.source: Use the Windows ICD CLI to customize and build a mobile image
segment.target: Use the Windows ICD CLI to customize and build a mobile image

segment.source: Use the Windows ICD CLI to customize and build a mobile image
segment.target: Use the Windows ICD CLI to customize and build a mobile image

segment.source: You can use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) command-line interface (CLI) to generate a new Windows 10 Mobile image.
segment.target: You can use the Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD) command-line interface (CLI) to generate a new Windows 10 Mobile image.

segment.source: This imaging method requires a pre-installed OS kit so you must have all the necessary Microsoft OS packages and feature manifest files in your default install path.
segment.target: This imaging method requires a pre-installed OS kit so you must have all the necessary Microsoft OS packages and feature manifest files in your default install path.

segment.source: You also need either a BSP.config.xml file, which contains information about the hardware component packages for your board support package (BSP) or you can use an OEMInput.xml file.
segment.target: You also need either a BSP.config.xml file, which contains information about the hardware component packages for your board support package (BSP) or you can use an OEMInput.xml file.

segment.source: If you're using a BSP.config.xml file, you can:
segment.target: If you're using a BSP.config.xml file, you can:

segment.source: Use the BSP.config.xml file you downloaded as part of the BSP kit, or,
segment.target: Use the BSP.config.xml file you downloaded as part of the BSP kit, or,

segment.source: Generate your own BSP.config.xml by running the BSP kit configuration tools from the SoC vendor and selecting your component drivers.
segment.target: Generate your own BSP.config.xml by running the BSP kit configuration tools from the SoC vendor and selecting your component drivers.

segment.source: Create a WPAF with multivariant support
segment.target: Create a WPAF with multivariant support

segment.source: Multivariant provides a generic mechanism for creating a single image that can work for multiple markets.
segment.target: Multivariant provides a generic mechanism for creating a single image that can work for multiple markets.

segment.source: You can use it to dynamically configure language, branding, and network settings during runtime based on the mobile operator and locale/country.
segment.target: You can use it to dynamically configure language, branding, and network settings during runtime based on the mobile operator and locale/country.

segment.source: Unlike the Windows ICD UI, you can use the Windows ICD CLI to to create an image that has multivariant support.
segment.target: Unlike the Windows ICD UI, you can use the Windows ICD CLI to to create an image that has multivariant support.

segment.source: In order to do this, you must first edit a Windows Provisioning answer file (WPAF), customizations.xml, and add the Targets and Variant sections to the file.
segment.target: In order to do this, you must first edit a Windows Provisioning answer file (WPAF), customizations.xml, and add the Targets and Variant sections to the file.

segment.source: Create a provisioning package with multivariant settings provides a more information about multivariant support in Windows 10 and a list of the conditions that Windows supports along with their priorities.
segment.target: Create a provisioning package with multivariant settings provides a more information about multivariant support in Windows 10 and a list of the conditions that Windows supports along with their priorities.

segment.source: It also provides a step-by-step example on what you need to do.
segment.target: It also provides a step-by-step example on what you need to do.

segment.source: In this section, we'll modify the customizations.xml file that was created from Use the Windows ICD UI to customize and build a mobile image and include Targets and Variant sections to support multivariant.
segment.target: In this section, we'll modify the customizations.xml file that was created from Use the Windows ICD UI to customize and build a mobile image and include Targets and Variant sections to support multivariant.

segment.source: If you are building a single variant image, you may skip this section.
segment.target: If you are building a single variant image, you may skip this section.

segment.source: Locate the provisioning package file, customizations.xml.
segment.target: Locate the provisioning package file, customizations.xml.

segment.source: If you didn't change the default project location, you can find the package in drive:UsersusernameDocumentsWindows Imaging and Configuration Designer (WICD)projectname.
segment.target: If you didn't change the default project location, you can find the package in drive:UsersusernameDocumentsWindows Imaging and Configuration Designer (WICD)projectname.

segment.source: Use an XML or text editor to open the customizations.xml file.
segment.target: Use an XML or text editor to open the customizations.xml file.

segment.source: The following example shows the contents of the customizations.xml file created in Use the Windows ICD UI to customize and build a mobile image.
segment.target: The following example shows the contents of the customizations.xml file created in Use the Windows ICD UI to customize and build a mobile image.

segment.source: Edit the customizations.xml file and create a Targets section to describe the conditions that will handle your multivariant settings.
segment.target: Edit the customizations.xml file and create a Targets section to describe the conditions that will handle your multivariant settings.

segment.source: The following example shows the customizations.xml, which has been modified to include the conditions MCC and MNC.
segment.target: The following example shows the customizations.xml, which has been modified to include the conditions MCC and MNC.

segment.source: For parity, the example uses the same fictitious IDs and conditions that were used in Create an MCSF customization answer file section in Configure customization settings.
segment.target: For parity, the example uses the same fictitious IDs and conditions that were used in Create an MCSF customization answer file section in Configure customization settings.

segment.source: In the customizations.xml file, create two Variant sections:
segment.target: In the customizations.xml file, create two Variant sections:

segment.source: Specify a Name for each variant.
segment.target: Specify a Name for each variant.

segment.source: Add a child TargetRefs element.
segment.target: Add a child TargetRefs element.

segment.source: Within the TargetRefs element, add a TargetRef element.
segment.target: Within the TargetRefs element, add a TargetRef element.

segment.source: The following example shows what the customizations.xml looks like after adding two variants, ThePhoneCompany and Fabrikam, and then using the two Target Ids we defined in the previous step to use as the TargetRef Id for each variant.
segment.target: The following example shows what the customizations.xml looks like after adding two variants, ThePhoneCompany and Fabrikam, and then using the two Target Ids we defined in the previous step to use as the TargetRef Id for each variant.

segment.source: Move compliant settings from the Common section to the Variant section.
segment.target: Move compliant settings from the Common section to the Variant section.

segment.source: Note Settings that reside in the Common section are applied unconditionally on every triggering event.
segment.target: Note Settings that reside in the Common section are applied unconditionally on every triggering event.

segment.source: In the following example, we used the policy under ThePhoneCompany variant while the policy was moved under the Fabrikam variant.
segment.target: In the following example, we used the policy under ThePhoneCompany variant while the policy was moved under the Fabrikam variant.

segment.source: Save the updated customizations.xml file and note the path to this updated file.
segment.target: Save the updated customizations.xml file and note the path to this updated file.

segment.source: You will need the path as one of the values when you get ready to build the image.
segment.target: You will need the path as one of the values when you get ready to build the image.

segment.source: Use the Windows ICD command-line interface (CLI) to create a provisioning package using the updated customizations.xml.
segment.target: Use the Windows ICD command-line interface (CLI) to create a provisioning package using the updated customizations.xml.

segment.source: For more information about how to build a provisioning package and a description of the command switches and parameters, see To build a provisioning package in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.
segment.target: For more information about how to build a provisioning package and a description of the command switches and parameters, see To build a provisioning package in Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: In this example, the StoreFile corresponds to the location of the settings store that will be used to create the package for the required Windows edition.
segment.target: In this example, the StoreFile corresponds to the location of the settings store that will be used to create the package for the required Windows edition.

segment.source: Note The provisioning package created during this step will contain the multivariant settings.
segment.target: Note The provisioning package created during this step will contain the multivariant settings.

segment.source: You can use this package either as a standalone package that you can apply to a Windows device, use it as the base when starting another project, or use it as one of one of the inputs (/ProvisioningPackage) when building either a Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education) image or Windows 10 Mobile image.
segment.target: You can use this package either as a standalone package that you can apply to a Windows device, use it as the base when starting another project, or use it as one of one of the inputs (/ProvisioningPackage) when building either a Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education) image or Windows 10 Mobile image.

segment.source: Build a mobile image using the Windows ICD CLI
segment.target: Build a mobile image using the Windows ICD CLI

segment.source: This walkthrough shows how to use the Windows ICD CLI to build a mobile image.
segment.target: This walkthrough shows how to use the Windows ICD CLI to build a mobile image.

segment.source: For more information about the Windows ICD CLI, including usage examples and parameter descriptions, see Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.
segment.target: For more information about the Windows ICD CLI, including usage examples and parameter descriptions, see Use the Windows ICD command-line interface.

segment.source: Open a command-line window with administrator rights.
segment.target: Open a command-line window with administrator rights.

segment.source: From the command-line, navigate to the Windows ICD install directory:
segment.target: From the command-line, navigate to the Windows ICD install directory:

segment.source: On an x64 computer, go to: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86
segment.target: On an x64 computer, go to: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86

segment.source: On an x86 computer, go to: C:Program FilesWindows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86
segment.target: On an x86 computer, go to: C:Program FilesWindows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitImaging and Configuration Designerx86

segment.source: Using the updated customizations.xml (with multivariant settings) and the MCSF CAF created in Configure customization settings, use the Windows ICD CLI to build a mobile image.
segment.target: Using the updated customizations.xml (with multivariant settings) and the MCSF CAF created in Configure customization settings, use the Windows ICD CLI to build a mobile image.

segment.source: To do this with the example files and using a bsp.config.xml, see the following command:
segment.target: To do this with the example files and using a bsp.config.xml, see the following command:

segment.source: Here are a few things to keep in mind:
segment.target: Here are a few things to keep in mind:

segment.source: Replace all the placeholder values for each parameter with the values that match your assets and directory locations
segment.target: Replace all the placeholder values for each parameter with the values that match your assets and directory locations

segment.source: Specify /ImageType because we are using /BSPConfigFile
segment.target: Specify /ImageType because we are using /BSPConfigFile

segment.source: Use /CustomizationXML to point to the customizations.xml
segment.target: Use /CustomizationXML to point to the customizations.xml

segment.source: Windows ICD requires /OEMCustomizationVer if ProvisioningPackage is defined
segment.target: Windows ICD requires /OEMCustomizationVer if ProvisioningPackage is defined

segment.source: Make sure the format for the /OEMCustomizationVer version number is in Major.Minor.SubVersion.SubMinorVersion, such as 1.0.0.0
segment.target: Make sure the format for the /OEMCustomizationVer version number is in Major.Minor.SubVersion.SubMinorVersion, such as 1.0.0.0

segment.source: To do this with the example files and using an OEMInput.xml file, see the following command:
segment.target: To do this with the example files and using an OEMInput.xml file, see the following command:

segment.source: Once the image (FFU) is built, you can flash it to your mobile device by using ffutool.exe or the Deploy option in the Windows ICD UI.
segment.target: Once the image (FFU) is built, you can flash it to your mobile device by using ffutool.exe or the Deploy option in the Windows ICD UI.

segment.source: See the following section for more information.
segment.target: See the following section for more information.

segment.source: Flash an image to a mobile device
segment.target: Flash an image to a mobile device

segment.source: There are two ways that you can use to flash an image to a mobile device:
segment.target: There are two ways that you can use to flash an image to a mobile device:

segment.source: Using ffutool.exe, or,
segment.target: Using ffutool.exe, or,

segment.source: Using the built-in flashing functionality in Windows ICD
segment.target: Using the built-in flashing functionality in Windows ICD

segment.source: This section shows how to do both.
segment.target: This section shows how to do both.

segment.source: Choose one of these methods to flash your image to your mobile device.
segment.target: Choose one of these methods to flash your image to your mobile device.

segment.source: Follow these steps if you are flashing the image to the device using Windows ICD.
segment.target: Follow these steps if you are flashing the image to the device using Windows ICD.

segment.source: To flash an image using Windows ICD
segment.target: To flash an image using Windows ICD

segment.source: Boot the device into image or FFU download mode.
segment.target: Boot the device into image or FFU download mode.

segment.source: To force your phone into image or FFU download mode manually, press and release the power button to reboot the phone and then immediately press and hold the volume up button.
segment.target: To force your phone into image or FFU download mode manually, press and release the power button to reboot the phone and then immediately press and hold the volume up button.

segment.source: Note that this option is available only after an initial FFU has been flashed to the phone.
segment.target: Note that this option is available only after an initial FFU has been flashed to the phone.

segment.source: If this doesn't work, check and follow the device flashing instructions provided by the SoC vendor.
segment.target: If this doesn't work, check and follow the device flashing instructions provided by the SoC vendor.

segment.source: Using a USB cable, connect your phone to the host computer.
segment.target: Using a USB cable, connect your phone to the host computer.

segment.source: Launch Windows ICD.
segment.target: Launch Windows ICD.

segment.source: Click Deploy from the main menu and choose To USB connected device to deploy the FFU image to the device.
segment.target: Click Deploy from the main menu and choose To USB connected device to deploy the FFU image to the device.

segment.source: In the Select an FFU image window, click Browse... to launch File Explorer and select the FFU that you want to flash to your target device, and then click Next.
segment.target: In the Select an FFU image window, click Browse... to launch File Explorer and select the FFU that you want to flash to your target device, and then click Next.

segment.source: Choose the target device or drive from the list.
segment.target: Choose the target device or drive from the list.

segment.source: If your device or drive is not listed, click Refresh.
segment.target: If your device or drive is not listed, click Refresh.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: In the Deploy to device window, choose Flash to start flashing the image.
segment.target: In the Deploy to device window, choose Flash to start flashing the image.

segment.source: Click Finish to close the Deployment page.
segment.target: Click Finish to close the Deployment page.

segment.source: Follow these steps if you are flashing the image to the device using ffutool.exe.
segment.target: Follow these steps if you are flashing the image to the device using ffutool.exe.

segment.source: To flash an image using ffutool.exe
segment.target: To flash an image using ffutool.exe

segment.source: Boot the device into FFU flashing mode while it is connected to the host computer.
segment.target: Boot the device into FFU flashing mode while it is connected to the host computer.

segment.source: If you didn't include the LABIMAGE optional feature when generating your test image, you can force the device into FFU flashing mode manually by pressing and releasing the power button to boot the device and then immediate pressing and holding the volume up button.
segment.target: If you didn't include the LABIMAGE optional feature when generating your test image, you can force the device into FFU flashing mode manually by pressing and releasing the power button to boot the device and then immediate pressing and holding the volume up button.

segment.source: However, note that this option is only available if an FFU has been initially flashed to the device.
segment.target: However, note that this option is only available if an FFU has been initially flashed to the device.

segment.source: Open a command prompt with administrator rights.
segment.target: Open a command prompt with administrator rights.

segment.source: Run ffutool.exe from the command line to flash the image.
segment.target: Run ffutool.exe from the command line to flash the image.

segment.source: ffutool -flash TestFlash.ffu
segment.target: ffutool -flash TestFlash.ffu

segment.source: No matter which method you used to flash the image to the device, it will take a few minutes for the image to be fully flashed.
segment.target: No matter which method you used to flash the image to the device, it will take a few minutes for the image to be fully flashed.

segment.source: Once flashing is done, go through device setup and verify that your customizations appear as part of the image.
segment.target: Once flashing is done, go through device setup and verify that your customizations appear as part of the image.
